segments.text: The meter begins to kick in.
It means we've begun to record.
It's essentially identification by name.
Identification by name and your affiliation with Woods Hole.
Okay.
It's your turn.
I'm H. Burr Steinbach.
Henry is the name, part of the first initial.
Henry Burr Steinbach, commonly known as Burr.
I have been associated with Woods Hole Oceanographic and with oceanography.
really for only about six or eight years.
I became the first dean of the graduate school of oceanography, and following after six months in which K.O.
Emery really set the thing up in good shape.
That's been my primary experience, except for a whole series of committees.
What was your early academic training?
Early academic training was essentially basic biology and general physiology.
And where did you go to school?
Undergraduate at Michigan, master's degree at Brown University, Ph.D. at the University of Pennsylvania, and a couple years of post-doc work.
Somehow I have you identified more with medical school, in my mind.
Is that incorrect?
Professional jobs have always been with departments of biology and zoology.
But I've been closely affiliated with medical schools and taught in medical schools during the war.
A field of teaching there was physiology.
In my professional field, it would be called biophysics.
And biophysics.
And how did you develop an interest in oceanography or becoming dean of Woods Hole?
partly because I've been associated with the Woodsville community since 1929, which is a long time away, and witnessed the growth of the oceanography here.
And then some years ago, dates I'd have to get you from the record, some years ago it was decided that it was necessary in the
old interagency committee on oceanography to have some general biologists associated with it.
So I became a member of the advisory committee for the old ICO.
How were you chosen for the ICO?
As you know, the way in which one gets into these things.
I had been
I'd been mixed up with the medical field on the National Heart Council, and then I also was chairman of the Division of Biology and Agriculture of the National Research Council.
And that, in turn, led me to association with the conferences that the National Academy would have up here at Woods Hole.
And being involved in those conferences, I got rather well acquainted with such people as Jim Wakeland, who at that time was Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
and Edward Wink, who became very firmly involved, of course, in the development of governmental support of oceanography.
So it's another one of those instances that is your personal acquaintances and development of interest in the field by association with these people.
Were you happy with the functioning of ICO?
Very much so.
I think they did a great deal of good at that time.
even though it didn't lead to any of the legislation that we would occasionally recommend.
What seemed to be the breakdown between the ICO and legislation?
Well, the structure of the ICO really was the assigned leadership of the various branches of the government, and they had no power.
In other words, there'd be meetings, there'd be recommendations, it would be a device for all of the different agencies to know what was going on.
But each agency still did as it pleased, so that it had no basic structure other than that of information and advisory.
But I think it had a very good influence in that effect.
With whom did you serve on the ICO?
Let me rephrase the question, please.
Was there anyone with whom you were particularly impressed
with in serving on the ICO?
Well, yes, indeed, they had some remarkable oceanographers.
Morris Ewing, for example, was on that.
That's where I got well acquainted with Morris Ewing.
Brackett Hersey from here was a member of it.
Hank Arnold, who is now running the State Department of Science.
And the things, they were quite a series of people, extraordinarily able people, as you might say.
which always gave me a feeling of slight bemusement because here I was, essentially a medical biophysicist operating with these characters who really were the basis for modern oceanography.
What was Morris Ewing like in committee assignments?
Very intelligent, very innovative, and very, you might say, very personal in the sense that he didn't want anyone else to run him.
I still remember him getting up at one of the meetings and essentially saying, why doesn't the damn Navy support our boat and keep their fingers off the boat?
We know how to run it.
Morris was one of the great people of oceanography.
There's just no doubt about it.
But he was absolutely devoted to going ahead and doing what he, with his
large quota of friends decided were the proper things to do in oceanography.
He had a great influence on the development of oceanography.
But as a committee member, he was also great because you could always rely on him to express his opinion.
Were there any particular recommendations coming out of ICO which you supported strongly, which were not developed?
It's a little hard to remember.
That was quite some years ago.
We did put in a very strong plug

for the assumption by the government of the total costs of oceanographic surveys because many of the oceanographers of course are working on specific problems the contours of the bottom of the ocean or the effects of the currents or the distribution of the benthic organisms and things like that
And they're somewhat less interested in taking worldwide surveys of the total oceans.
And at that time, there was no such thing as the DOE in the, well, it was before the geophysical year, whatever it was called.
I forgot.
International geophysical year.
So it seemed highly important that there be a concentrated effort for the federal government to take over the responsibility of making sure that there were these ocean-wide surveys.
Now, that was not acted upon at that time.
But as you know, there had been a series of developments, mostly, well, some national, quite a few of them international.
And how much those developments stemmed from the discussions and recommendations of ICO would be very hard to define.
But the recommendations were there, and they probably had an influence.
After your service on the committee, then what did you do?
Well, I was briefly on the NASCO committee, but I resigned from that.
Actually, that overlapped with ICO, and I resigned from that because I went in and informed them.
I thought there was a little conflict of interest there because they were criticizing the ICO operations, and I was being an ardent supporter of ICO.
Then at the time when the Council on Marine Science and Development
that was the government equivalent of the Stratton Commission.
And Ed Wink was in charge of that.
So he brought me in as consultant on that for two or three years.
That was also a very exciting thing because Ed Wink was also quite a personality, as you probably know in case you've interviewed him.
And then also at just about that time,
Sea Grant program was started.

And since I had worked very closely with Bob Abel on the old ICO thing, and also had been an assistant director of the National Science Foundation, a few things like that, I became one of the first members of the Sea Grant Advisory Program.
So there's a continuity.
I have several questions.
Probably working backwards.
In working with Wink, what exactly were you trying to do?
Well, the Council had the overall responsibility for the coordination and development of all marine sciences.
So that what we would do, we would have, among other things, a series of committee meetings to...
put out the annual reports that were necessary and were required.
And, of course, those reports, I don't know, you can never tell how much influence they had, but after all, the chairman of this council was by...
By law, the vice president of the United States, and Humphrey at that time, was extraordinarily interested in marine sciences.
So the main thing that we did, that his advisory group did, was to put together the progress for a given year to provide the material to write the report.
And as a matter of fact, I was involved with Ed frequently
the final hectic moments when you had to get the damn report out.
So that's it.
And you'll find the reports, of course, have been written, and you'll see their recommendations.
And this is all being done parallel with, I might say, the NASCO committee reports and several other National Academy of Sciences reports and a follow-on from the ICO.
There's a continuity between them.
Did you feel as if when Humphrey left, that sort of the drive for oceanography left with him?
Oh, Christ, not only left, it disappeared.
I wasn't at the meeting, but because the advisory committee meeting did not meet with the council.
They were advisory to the director of the thing.
But the story is that when Agnew came into office, that he attended one meeting,
part of it, and left and came back the second meeting and stayed five minutes and got up and said, sorry, gentlemen, I'm interested in space.
And bang!
Shortly after that, the council did expire.
Sea Grant.
Now, second question.
When did you become interested in the idea of Sea Grant?
When did you first hear about it?
Well, I've been
fairly close associated with Athol Spilhaus, you see.
Because I taught at Minnesota when Athol was dean of the technology out there.
And you don't be associated with Athol Spilhaus without knowing an awful lot of things that he's thinking about.
So that I would say practically from when he first invented the term.
And liked the idea very much, I might say.
You liked the idea?
Oh, yes.
What was Spilhaus like to work for?
There have been some criticisms of him as dean in Minnesota.
That would require another whole book to write about Raphael Spilhaus.
He's a most remarkable person.
He has an ability to define objectives.
And he also has the ability to point fingers at people and say, get ahead, go do it.
So that some of the, I suspect that some of the flack at Minnesota was primarily because he was not one to just sit behind a desk and be an orderly operator.
He is a man of ideas, he develops ideas, and he does have a considerable ability to get people to go do the work for him.
Oh yes, I'm sure you couldn't possibly work with, Spilhaus couldn't possibly work in an institution not to get some criticism, but the praise would exceed it with criticism.
When Spilhaus first begins to talk to you about Sea Grant, you remember what terms he phrased it?
Did he attach it immediately to land-grant colleges?
He did it by comparison.
That was

I wouldn't want to say that that's what stimulated his thinking on it, but being a good political thinker, I think he realized that a handle that would be recognized by people, including the legislators, would be this comparison with a land grant.
You have a land grant, so okay, damn it, let's have a sea grant, which is just important.
I suspect that was the reasoning.
The use of the term Sea Grant program was almost certainly suggested by the existence of land grant.

But I don't think that it was the, I might say, the success or an existence of land grant that led into the concept that we ought to really start developing programs for the proper and effective utilization of marine resources.
Now, when you first began to be associated with Sea Grant, what were the problems involved in
originating Sea Grant and picking Sea Grant institutions?
Well, the problems involved were, they rested upon the, a little bit on the Land Grant Association, that you would make use of academic institutions.
And since the philosophy of Sea Grant, in the same way that Land Grant is, that this be a system in which you really try to improve the utilization
of something.
In other words, it becomes what some people call applied science.

And introducing that into departments of biology or departments of chemistry or departments of whatever in the academic institution is extraordinarily difficult, because they are convinced that their main function in life is to follow what they then consider the basic problems in a particular field.
And Sea Grant is pretty pervasive.
If you make use of the total resources of the oceans, you can't just be a biologist, or you can't just be a chemist, or you can't be what else.
You have to be what ecology ought to be, but this wasn't at that time.
You have to be a little of everything.
In other words, you have to be able to define rather broad problems that lead to a practical usage right away.
You're associated almost immediately with Bob Abel, I take it.
Oh, yes.
And I had been associated.
See, he was the ICO when I was working there.
Ed Link was with the PSAC.
Jim Wakeland, as Assistant Secretary of the Navy, was in charge of ICO.
And Bob Abel, being with the Navy at that time, was
essentially the director for Wakeland.
That is, Wakeland's appointee as director of Sea Grant.
So I worked with Bob Abel.
I'd worked with him for quite some time.
He's with us now at A&M.
Don't I know it.
I take it you found him efficient and those sorts of things which make a good administrator?
Oh, very.
He also had a remarkable knack of finding some excellent people to work with him.
And the Sea Grant staff is pretty remarkable in that respect.
When you first begin to designate Sea Grant colleges, how do you go about designating them?
Well, the first thing that, of course, it became known that there was Sea Grant money and various colleges put in.
And that's where the first successful Sea Grant program really was the Oregon State University.
For some reason or other,
Sorry, I can't remember the name of the guy.
Wayne Burke?
Hmm?
Wayne Burke?
I don't think Wayne Burke.
There are a couple of people out there who grasp the concept right away on the thing.
But with most of the other schools that we first started doing things with, it was a very hard job to get them to agree to the concept of Sea Grant.
And the way in which that was done was not only that Bob Abel and his staff were excluding Abel people, but they also used their advisory committee.
They'd go out and have meetings at the end of the advisory committee.

Bob Abel and usually two or three of the advisory committee would go up and talk with the boss man of the university and once in a while have to pound the table and say, either you can persuade your departmental people
to agree to this concept, or you better not even try to get into Sea Grant.
I would say that the first five years, there was one really of educating the academic institutions to subscribe to the concept of Sea Grant.
And of course, John Calhoun was very early in that.
And he was also one of the first members of the Sea Grant Advisory Program.
But then he resigned when he
when it was quite clear that A&M was going to be a leader in Sea Grant, too.
But he's been very influential in general advisory work, too.
Have you been satisfied with the outcome of Sea Grant?
Yes.
For the first 10-year development, I think it was excellent.
I think that the next 10 years is...
It's really, in a sense, more challenging, and that is to how to meld it together into much more of a national program.
You've got the parts now.
You have the various units of a program.
Now to define more nearly some of the national objectives and to get a more concerted effort on those.
After Sea Grant, then what?
After Sea Grant, what do you mean after Sea Grant?
What did you do next?
Oh, of course they just kicked me off the Sea Grant Advisory Panel.
Coincidence with that, I got to retirement age at the University of Chicago.
So I moved here to Woods Hole and became a
president and director of MBL on a sort of an interim basis because I was getting a little too old to do that.
But there was an overlap of time here.
In other words, I had revamped the Department of Chicago and brought in zoology and botany together in biology, which was a good time for me to get out of the chairmanship there.
So rather than waiting to age 65, I guess I was 63, I came here then to take over running a marine biological laboratory.
But they also have a stipulation that at age 65 you retire.
So after the two and, well, three years of running it, really, we were developing the graduate program at Woods Hole Oceanographic.
And I was very interested in that.
because it's part of Woods Hole life.
And I'm not institution-minded, should we say.
I love Woods Hole as a basic community.

So when they were having great difficulty in finding a professional oceanographer who would sort of run a chance on trying to put together a graduate school, and with a general academic background, they finally, we finally reached an agreement, okay, I'd start the graduate school up there.
So that's sort of the sequence of things overlapping.
First, working with the lab, did you go to the lab with any preconceived ideas of what you wanted to do?
Which lab?
The MBL.
Well, it's been a major source of my research work, of course.
Well, to pick an example, I was one of the first ones to start using the giant squid axon as a device for really medical physiology and things like that.
And that's been mostly my existence there.
So to say the involvement with the administrative end of things and the overall planning of things didn't take place until about age 55.
Before that, I really was an academic.
laboratory type, you might say.
You worked with the squid, though, for G, you know, I guess 20 years almost, didn't you?
No, not that long, because my interest was really, say, biophysics, and had to do with particularly electrolyte transfer between cells in the environment.
So it's quite a spread of materials that I used, ranging pretty much from frog skin, muscle tissue, some kidney work, things like that.
So at that time, I was being a very good academic.
In other words, you have an objective and use the material that's best.
And squid nerves, of course, turned out to be one of the most remarkable findings.
You didn't carry out any major reorganization of the lab when you arrived?
At the MBL?
Yeah, at the MBL.
No, except that while I was there, we did start some of the year-round programs.
You see, the MBL had always been really primarily a summer program.
It became perfectly clear that one needed to get more year-round programs going for

for a very practical reason, and that is that people would come to, we'd ask foundations for support, and they'd come and look at all those nice buildings there and find them used only four months out of the year, and they'd just get into all sorts of tizzies.
So for a purely practical reason, it became necessary to try to begin to bring more outside things in, which my successor, Jim Ebert, has been remarkably successful at doing.
But during the...
During the three or four years in which I was director of the NBL, we did start that year-round program.
How did you aim for a year-round program?
What sort of changes did you make to create one?
No changes, in effect.
It's primarily a matter of finding ways to do it, which means money.
That just had to do with interesting various units.
One of the main things that we started then was this Boston University program, which is working very well.
In a sense, that wasn't so much a matter of money as it was getting some very good people working here year-round who could pay for themselves.
And how did you solicit them?
Again, that has a rather odd history.
At the time that I was the
assistant director of the Science Foundation.
This goes way back to, what, 53.
And then following that, I was chairman of the divisional committee.
And at that time, some of the people at Boston University wanted to start their own marine laboratory.
And the problems of financing to really establish a proper marine laboratory were not very good.

During the various discussions, which lasted over several years, you see, really quite a few years, I became acquainted with some of the people at Boston University, and we finally arrived at the conclusion that the sensible thing, if they wanted a marine sciences program, would be to utilize an existing facility.
That's roughly the way in which it developed.
Okay.
And so then when you become director, I suppose you...
Didn't make overtures to them to use the facilities?
Yes, it was one of those things that, again, I'm trying to remember the name of the man mainly involved who left and is now down in South Carolina.
It was mainly a thing that we'd been having discussions all along.
And prior to that, there was no really easy administrative link at which you could do the planning.
But when I came into the office and already had the contacts with Boston University, it wasn't a matter of anyone making overtures.
It was a matter of just saying, ha, goddammit, now we can get going.
So then you just began to move?
Yeah.
All right.
And some very interesting administrative discussions, I might say.
But it led to the formation of, I think, a very good program now, which also made it much easier.
The existence of that made it much easier to get the other year-round programs started.
You have to have a nugget to start with, you see.
And it's while you're there, is this when you begin to make formal contact with now
The Woods Hole staff?
No, I'd really known a fairish number of them for quite some time.
Woods Hole is that sort of a community, even though the institutions are separate.
On the scientific staff basis, no one makes any separations.
Depends on your interest in science.
So the answer is, no, I'd known them quite a bit.

And then, of course, when I became director and became more closely associated with Paul Fye, it was, well, we agreed upon something which is extraordinarily important and still is, and that is that Woods Hole is a total scientific community.
And you do have to make sure that even though the separate institutions retain their individual integrity, that nevertheless they do not act competitively.
have to act cooperatively.
So Paul and I agreed on that very thoroughly.
And that led to quite a close association.
And when then do you think about becoming director or dean over here at Woods Hole?
I was involved in the search committee.
Oh, okay.
And it really was one of those cases
It would be very hard to get a top-level prestigious oceanographer to come in and run a chance on cutting down his own scientific productivity to start up something new like that, you see.
So that I don't remember, and I wouldn't mention anyway, the people, we had two or three people that we really tried to put the bee on.
But if you're mixed up in academia, you'll know that if there's a position open and you track a couple people, then if you go much further than that, the prestige of the job sort of goes down.
It's pretty clear, and this is my reasoning really, because as I pointed out to the rest of the search committee,
I had no experience in either oceanography or being a dean or anything else, so what the hell.
But then we also decided that everyone would give me complete backing and support.
And I didn't really need those skills.
All they needed was someone to get the balloon thing started.
And that's a nice challenge.
